author: afdudley
content: What incentive to miners have to include 1559 transactions over legacy? What incentive do users have to submit 1559 tx over legacy?

author: sky.cactus
content: For the latter question, this is a long winded "story mode" answer: https://medium.com/@MicahZoltu/a-tale-of-two-pricing-schemes-dc9c8717906

author: sky.cactus
content: Not a concise one-paragraph technical answer though, which perhaps is more what you are looking for?

author: sky.cactus
content: Miners are incentivized to include all eligible transactions that pay them more than their uncle risk for inclusion up until the block is full, after that they preference transactions by which pay a higher fee to the miner.  This is because any transactions they *don't* include that meet those requirements is just money left on the table for the next miner.

author: sky.cactus
content: Users are incentivized to use 1559 transactions because they can over-bid on gas without having to overpay in the vast majority of cases.

author: barnabemonnot
content:
hi Rick, I wrote a bit about it here: https://barnabemonnot.com/abm1559/notebooks/transition1559.html

in my opinion we are not going to see legacy users overpay that much, as long as their wallets quote prices the way they do now. if you have enough 1559 users, the oracles should broadly quote something close to the basefee (since oracles rely on existing and previous demand), meaning that as they send their transactions, legacy users might already not make the cut if they are at or close to basefee. so rather than they are overpaying, I think they are losing on inclusion time and certainty. you can see in this section for instance: https://barnabemonnot.com/abm1559/notebooks/transition1559.html#subsec-4-1
